237311039.description:
In public-key cryptography, a key signing party is an event at which people present their public keys to others in person. The key signing party facilitates web of trust approach.


And no worries, Security can be fun, the Key-signing PaRtY will include light snack and drinks.


Have a key - come to share with others. Don’t have - we will help to create new one.

This event follows to the event of 2015 https://www.meetup.com/seoul-tech-society/events/223269564/

Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) improves the security and trust in messages, documents, software and other data published from you or your company.


The event will include a brief introduction to PKI as well as a hands-on part and a key-signing party, don't miss fun.

Agenda:

* features the Key-signing PaRtY.

• 5:00pm, Gates Open

• 5:30pm, PKI introduction and Hands-on: generate and use Keys - GPG (Windows, OSX, Linux) – Bring your laptops to follow along 

• 6:30pm, Key-signing PaRtY 

https://goo.gl/forms/iNoXYza7HrNda5V63 please, fill the form so


in order to facilitate the event, we will have a list of public keys and a way to contact owners. Also, when you exchange your key in person, you would need to confirm your identity, bring IDs (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Key_signing_party&sa=D&ust=1485800641341000&usg=AFQjCNGMzQd1xf39WUa1JJRUJf0sNlDCUg">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Key_signing_party)
237311039.title: Get a Key 2017

219824218.description:
Emily's "civic hacking story from San Francisco to Seoul" will share her experiences working on a civic tech project in San Francisco, how it changed her life and helped bring her to Korea.

This is a collaborative event with Code for Seoul, a civic hacking community which tries to make our community and city better by coding.

Story:

Emily's researching is on Korean tech, focusing specifically on the sharing economy as a strategy for urban sustainable development.  During the first half of her grant year, she focused on learning broadly about the Korean start up ecosystem, which is just starting to emerge from the shadows of the large Chaebols.  The challenges facing start ups in Korea are immense, given that the start-up mentality is the opposite of traditional Korean business culture; however, there are many unique opportunities for tech start ups in Korea as well, a future-thinking culture with incredible tech infrastructure and hardware manufacturing expertise.  Nonetheless it may take a generational shift to fully realize this potential.  
In the next stage of her research, she hopes to conduct a case study of AirBnB hosts in Yeonnam-dong, Seoul  to examine the social, environmental, and economic benefits of the sharing economy. 

Before coming to Korea, she worked on projects related to Internet law at the Berkman Center for Internet and Society, and in the Mayor's Office in San Francisco.

more in her talk...


Bio:

http://emilyhong.com/         @emilme

A recent graduate of Yale and current Fulbright scholar in South Korea researching the sharing economy, she hopes to build a career at the intersection of policy, law, and technology. This interest was ignited during a summer fellowship at the San Francisco Mayor’s Office in 2013. Working with the Mayor’s Office of Civic Innovation (MOCI) (and Code for America, the Open Gov Foundation, and Github), she helped start the SF Open Law Initiative to increase public access to legislative documents by making them available as open data.

Agenda:

7:30 - gate open
7:45 - intro about Code for Seoul and SeoulTech
7:50 - what is civic hacking?
8:00 - Emily's story
8:45 - civic hacking projects' ideas & demos
9:30 - after-party and socializing


We'll move to a bar nearby to have some beer, a good time and mix&mingle among seoultechies and code for seoul hackers.
219824218.title: [Collaborative event] Civic Hacking Story from San Francisco to Seoul

147208302.description:
We welcome a long-awaited practical workshop with Dr. Joshua James, which is our second event from the cyber security series. Bring your laptop to practice being a cyber-sleuth.

After a short discussion about the challenges with different data storage devices, we will learn to take a copy of Random Access Memory (USB stick for an advanced lab) and extract evidence of user activity, such as pictures, web addresses and etc.

Bonus

In addition, we will cover extracting passwords from memory.

============== What to bring ================

• Laptop


• USB stick or other storage device you want to recover data from (camera's SD card).


Windows Users:

• Download `FTK Imager Lite Version 3.1.1' [Free] (http://www.accessdata.com/support/product-downloads)


• Download `UnixUtils' [Free] (http://sourceforge.net/projects/unxutils/)


• Download `Testdisk & Photorec' [Free] (http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk_Download)


Mac Users:

• Download `Mac Memory Reader' [Free] (http://cybermarshal.com/index.php/cyber-marshal-utilities/mac-memory-reader)

• Download `Testdisk & Photorec' [Free] (http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk_Download)


Linux Users:

• Download `lime-forensics' [Free] (https://code.google.com/p/lime-forensics/)

• Download `Testdisk & Photorec' [Free] (http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk_Download)


Android Users (advanced):

• Rooted Android device

• Download `lime-forensics' [Free] (https://code.google.com/p/lime-forensics/)


• A laptop to do acquisition analysis on with requirements above.
147208302.title: Hands-on workshop: Data recovery from computer memory

234567273.description:
Update: it's on the 3rd floor, here are pictures of the building

In this talk, we'll analyse the Internet Censorship in Korea. Pierre will talk about different versions of HTTP protocol and how to have fun with them.


It will be not very technical, but we advise you to have some basic knowledge about L2/L3 network protocols and HTTP.

Agenda:

• 1. Introduction - AKA "doing OCR of Hangeul in an image"

• 2. Censorship in South Korea

• 3. Technical introduction about how "www.warning.or.kr" system work

• 4. Live Debugging session

• 5. Deductions

• 6. Using deductions, how to bypass the Great Wall of South Korea

• 7. PoC(s)

• 8. The Future


Topics Covered:

- NSFW

- L3 protocols

- HTTP protocols

- Routing

- Network stacks

- Encryption

Pierre is an IT security researcher. He likes offensive security and browsing Internet without censorship. His current researches are about how to hack IoT devices and how to find backdoors in systems. You can find his security blog @ https://pierrekim.github.io/

Other interests include 막걸리, Van Gogh paintings and Farnsworth's fusor.

Disclaimer: we would like to kindly ask all attendees to refrain from any audio/video or photo recordings during the event.
234567273.title: [Security] Internet Censorship in Korea - Technical Details

226645796.description:
Greetings fellow makers, tinkerers, designers, and inventors! We at Ateam Ventures and Fab Lab Seoul are excited to be hosting this event series with Seoul Tech Society.

안녕하세요 메이커, 디자이너 여러분. 저희 에이팀 벤처스, 팹랩 서울 팀원들은 Seoul Tech Society와  같이 이번 이벤트를 개최하게 되어 매우 흥분됩니다! :)


Why are we doing this? (우리는 왜 이것을 하고 있냐구요?)

Last workshop, we found that most of our participants were quite new to the 3D printing process. For this next workshop, we wanted to introduce the 3D printing process with a simple, practical, and festive activity. By attending, you will be walked through the entire 3D printing process, from design and 3D model slicing, all the way to printing and utilisation. Let me emphasise that this workshop is on the general process of 3D printing and not on any particular specifics.

What do we hope to accomplish? (우리는 무엇을 달성 희망 합니까?)

By the end of this workshop, you will feel comfortable enough with the 3D printing process to start exploring on your own, and to see the practical value of 3D printing.

What exactly will we be doing this coming meetup (November 21st)? (이번 모임에서 정확히 무엇을 하는건가요?(11/21))

We will guide you through the process of 3D printing your own (small) cookie cutter which you can use at home this holiday season to make fun cookie shapes! You will leave the workshop with a small 3D printed cookie cutter, the knowledge of how to process a 3D file for 3D printing, and some cookies as well (mmmmmm cookies)! All plastics used for this workshop will be food-safe so don't worry! 

For the 3D printing veterans, our acetone vapour chamber and tetrahydrofuran for polishing, and Dremel for friction welding will always be available for you to use at all of these workshops, regardless of the topic of that day. Feel free to wander comfortably between the organised workshop, and your personal, post processing projects. We will answer your questions or help you set something up whenever we get the chance ;)

What you need to bring

1) Yourself and any and all interested friends

2) 5,000 KRW cash to cover material costs (plastic for the 3D printers, and cookie dough) [All "profits" are donated to Fab Lab Seoul!]


3) Your plastic models (PLA and ABS) if you would like to do some polishing or friction welding outside of the organised workshop (totally free free free!)


How, where, and when are these events happening? (언제, 어디서, 어떻게 이벤트가 진행되는건가요?)

We plan on holding these "workshops" every other Saturday from 10:00 AM to 11:30 AM, the closest workshop being this November 21st [masked]) at Fab Lab Seoul. Eduardo Charmorro (Fab Lab Seoul) and Joseph Choi (Ateam Ventures) will be there at the very least to provide guidance as needed. We will be charging a minor fee to cover material costs (plastic for the 3D printers, dough for the cookies). As always, please consider donating to Fab Lab Seoul so we can keep on upgrading the tools and supplies we can provide both you and all your fellow makers! 

Suggest Resources

If you want to print a 3D model before coming but don't have printer, consider using Shapengine (http://www.shapengine.com/) website, they can print it for you before the event

Happy making!

Feel free to contact Joseph Choi at [masked] if you have any questions or suggestions. Hope to see you soon!

Location of Fab Lab Seoul

서울특별시 종로구 장사동 116-4 세운상가 550호

Jangsadong 116-4, Sewoon Sang-ga #550 Jong-Ro_Gu, Seoul, Korea


You can use Naver Maps to navigate to either (1) Jongno 3-Ga Station in the top left corner, (2) Euljiro 3-Ga Station in the bottom left corner, (3) Euljiro 4-Ga Station in the bottom right corner, and then get to Fab Lab Seoul by walking (it is on the 5th floor of the complex).

Just wanted to update the event with the design options for the cookie cutters tomorrow! After picking one of these designs, we will show you how to modify the settings in Cura, your slicing software, to print your cookie cutter quickly and with acceptable quality! :)

231353488.description:
A short talk about what it means to be a full stack UXer in the startup industry, and how it enables getting a lot more done in far less time.
Hila Yonatan, a UXer from Israel, brings ideas from her own experience in designing for startups and how she has achieved just that in her own career.  

About the talk

A full stack UXer belongs to a new breed of UX designers that has evolved in recent years. 
When UX designers begin taking on more aspects of the product’s experience and having a broader range of skills - they can be addressed as something more. 
When it happens, they are effectively managing and designing the experience as a whole, for the entire product. 

These UXers are quite rare, and are usually involved in startups, where a small team of talents is required to launch product under a short timeline. 
If you find one, or find that a UXer on your team is becoming one, you’d better keep them close! 

This lecture will be about:

• Learning a new concept and understanding if being a full stack UXer is a good fit for you
• Generally understanding what to expect from, or what you should do as a full stack UXer
• How acting as a full stack UXer reduces bottlenecks and speeds up the entire process

If you aim to increase your efficiency, you are welcome to attend and be inspired.
The speaker, Hila Yonatan, will provide examples from her own personal experience, and explain what it took to become a full stack UXer in a competitive market. 

She will talk about how these skills made it possible to take on a high profile project with only 2 days a week at the office. 

About the speaker 

Hila Yonatan is a full stack UX/UI designer and consultant from Israel. Over the past years, Hila has worked with several prominent startup teams, primarily in mobile applications. 
Hila led the Tel-Aviv team to the PayPal BattleHack 2015 World Finals, and is actively engaged in creating the next best experiences in every opportunity.
Additionally, she writes professional articles and tech related coverage in several online magazines, such as UX Magazine, GeekTime, Medium and a few others.

Seoul Tech Society, Seoul Bitcoin Meetup, and lead Korean Bitcoin startups Korbit and Coinplug will come together to discuss past, present, and future of cryptocurrencies. 

Great people and thought-provoking discussions are guaranteed!

Agenda

13:00 Reception 

13:15 Introduction to Bitcoin


Ruben Somsen, Seoul Bitcoin Meetup

13:40 The non-monetary applications of Bitcoin

Jason Park, Korbit 


14:20 Bitcoin adoption worldwide and Coinplug in Korea

Evelyn Chung, Coinplug  


14:50 Political and philosophical ideas behind the creation of cryptocurrency

Terry Jang, Hanapay


Hands-on part: 

15:30 Sending Money Abroad to and from Korea

Chris Williams


15:45 Bitcoin Wallets on iOS 

Jong Hun Kim 

16:00 Getting paid as a freelancer in Bitcoin

Ben McDonald 

16:15 Alternatives to Bitcoin: Alt Coins

Jeff Paik, bitPremierS


17:00 ~  After party and networking event 

We will go to one of those self-beer bar, they offer a wide variety of imported beers and cheap food.  There is one not far from Seolleung station:

맥주야 - address

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Speakers

Ruben Somsen 

Ruben is a freelance translator that has lived in Korea for three years. He is the organizer of the Seoul Bitcoin Meetup and knows a lot about the technical side of Bitcoin.

Jason Park, Korbit 

Jason is a senior developer at Korbit, which is South Korea's first and largest Bitcoin exchange and wallet company. 


Evelyn Chung, Coinplug 

Evelyn is Chief Marketing Officer of Coinplug, a Seoul-based Bitcoin startup. Coinplug provides a Bitcoin exchange and wallet services, and payment processor targeting Korean and Asian markets.


Terry Jang 

Terry Jang is the owner and president of Hanapay Ltd, an e-commerce consulting company and ISO (indepedent sales organization).
He bought his first bitcoins in 2011 because he thought investing in the first opensource decentralized transparent digital currency was the worth the gamble.
He had already experienced losses on the stock market and at the poker table.

Chris Williams


Chris is an English teacher who has lived and worked in Seoul for the past 2 years. Before that he lived in the UAE for 2 years. He became interested in bitcoin because it allows people to send any amount of money, anywhere in the world, instantly, and for free.


Jong Hun Kim


Jong Hun is a korean Bitcoin user. He's not a tech savvy guy, but is really interested in the bitcoin ecosystem and is currently researching and developing a Bitcoin fund.


Ben McDonald


Ben is a freelance web developer from New Zealand living in Seoul. Ask him anything about Bitcoin and he will give you an answer (after first asking Ruben what the answer is).

Jeff Paik

Jeff Paik is a writer for bitPremierS and co-founder of cryptocurrency advisory group Coinvest.

224398913.description:
SeoulTech's own hackathon! Whether you want to play with open-source devices, design interfaces or process data, we prepare Hack@Seoul to satisfy your curiosity and creativity.

Register until Aug,15: https://build-days.eventbrite.com  (more details inside)

Teams: up to 5 people

Provided devices: Arduino, Raspberry Pi, different sensors, Reco beacons, CISCO IP Camera, CISCO Edge340 ... bring your own (participants are already sharing Myo, Leapmotion, Muse and Emotiv) 

Hack@Seoul: Seoul Build Days is a collaborative initiative of Seoul Tech Society and Seoul Global Center. Our goal is to provide a vendor-agnostic, collaborative, and fun event with useful outcomes. Awards will find you anyway.


Concept


36 hours non-stop coding, but don't forget to meet peers. We want to reduce judging time to minimum, so you must learn what others will do for peers voting.

Main topic is open-source devices (like Arduino and Raspberry Pi), though we don't limit your creativity. Build software, hardware, UI or even physical elements*

Open-source devices provide you high-degree of flexibility to automate environment around you. Beacons-based services is another hot topic nowadays. Beacons enable location-based services for commercial venues, industrial spaces, offices, streets and even houses. Design and build your own beacon with Arduino or start working directly with services utilizing Reco beacons with easy to use SDK.

Korea is famous with its fastest and ubiquitous broadband which waits for integration of your services. CISCO provides us elements of its infrastructure which you can utilize to integrate your solutions.

All collected data and infrastructure are not useful if users don't have access to it. Another option for your project is to focus on elegant and usable applications.

We've elaborated on several areas where you can focus during the hackathon. They are stimulus for your imagination - Go beyond. Now is your time to choose what you want to build.  

* in order to use 3D printers, contact hosts prior to the event (at least one week)
224398913.title: Hackathon - Hack@Seoul: Seoul Build Days

238050818.description:
More and more daily life activities and businesses are coming online, as well as arising danger of web security threats. Moreover, technologies are getting more and more complicated, allowing more diverse attack vectors and cyber criminal use. The urgency to educate the public and to find ways to involve everybody in the discussion has never been greater.

Cyber Security experts from Horangi (horangi.com) will help us facilitate discussion about the current state of cyber security and why it is relevant for everyone: final users, small and medium businesses, independent developers and huge corporations.

사이버 보안 위협은 항상 유동적으로 발생하고 있습니다. 오늘 날, 많은 사업들이 첨단 기술에 기반하고 있으며, 이러한 요소들은 잠재적인 공격 대상으로 여겨집니다. 대중들에게 보안 문제의 중요성을 교육하고, 모두와 문제해결을 논의하는 것은 점차 중요시 되고 있습니다.

호랑이(horangi.com)의 사이버 보안 전문가들이 최신 사이버 보안 이슈와, 왜 그것이 모두에게 연관이 있는지를 강연할 예정입니다. 스타트업부터 중소기업, 독자적인 개발자 및 대기업까지 해당되는 내용인 만큼 많은 분들이 참석하셔서, 보다 폭넓은 의견 교류가 이루어지시길 바랍니다.

Target audience:

Anybody interested can attend, from startup founders, developers, to security professionals. If you are a startup owner operating online or a developer, you would learn what is the current state of cyber security in the web and how you can improve your position.

If you are a security professional, you are welcome to help us discuss how we can address existing security problems.

Agenda:

7:30pm :   Gates open

8pm       :   Introduction of web security state, by Horangi CTO

8:30pm :   Examples of web threats, by Horangi Lead CyOps Engineer

9pm       :   Discussion of the cyber security

-- from user perspective of view

-- from developer perspective of view

-- from business perspective of view

-- from cyber experts perspective of view

9:30pm  :   Mix & mingle

217756852.description:
[Autodesk Evening Meetup Seoul 2014 –with Seoul Tech Society] 

3D on the Web Night – Modeling, VR, WebGL, and three. js and more


For both web designers and software developers Jim Quanci and Philippe Leefsma from Autodesk will show how to make 3D models even more immersive and engaging on the Web , and then check out VR on the cheap with Google Cardboard.

AGENDA

7:00 ~ 8:00 PM: Doors Open. Finger food as you mix and mingle.

8:00 ~ 8:15 PM: Welcome & Announcements

8:15 ~ 8:40 PM: Presentation by Jim and Philippe - how to deliver immersive and engaging 3D models through your Web browser

8:40 ~8:50 PM: Break

8:50 ~9:20 PM: VR on the cheap with Google Cardboard and the Autodesk Viewing & Data web service

9:30 PM: Closing

WebGL is a very powerful technology for enriching the Web with graphics, but how do we get it into the hands of the creators? Jim and Philippe will go through some aspects of publishing and delivering 3D models on the WEB through a simple easy pipeline, providing coders, designers and artists alike with a strong and powerful 3D web graphics tool. Not only can you easily bring your 3D models to the WEB, but the Viewer (based on three. js) comes with an API which will allow you, your friends and your customers to interact with the 3D model and query elements’ metadata.

Then, Jim and Philippe will demonstrate how WebGL experiences created with the Autodesk engine can be elevated to the next level by delivering these 3D models through a simple web page to Google Cardboard VR (without your having to invest hours of time preparing and publishing your models).


For more about Autodesk’s 3D Web technologies check out developer.autodesk.com, and see an app demo at  http://autode.sk/m3w.


***Biography***

Jim Quanci (Director, Autodesk Developer Network)


With more than 25 years of engineering and design experience, Jim Quanci has spent the past 20 years developing relationships for Autodesk with leading technology partners around the world.  He oversees an international network of over 4,000 software partners – third-parties who customize, complement and extend Autodesk’s Desktop, Cloud and Mobile technologies. 

Along with founding the “Autodesk Developer Network”, and current worldwide responsibility for software partnerships at Autodesk, Jim’s experience working with Autodesk software partners includes stints managing partners in the Americas and Asia. Prior to Autodesk, Jim worked at Sun Microsystems and General Electric.  With a BS in Mechanical Engineering and an MBA in International Marketing, Jim is a frequent presenter and consultant to leading design and engineering software firms on software development technologies.

Philippe Leefsma (Technical Evangelist, Autodesk Developer Network)

Philippe has a master's degree in Computer Sciences. He carried his studies in Paris at I.S.E.P and in USA, at Colorado School of Mines. He joined Autodesk 8 years ago where he works as a technical evangelist for Autodesk Developer Network. He supports several Autodesk desktop products APIs, such as Inventor and AutoCAD. He is also investigating various technologies around the Cloud & Mobile area to share his experiences through a devblog: http://adndevblog.typepad.com/cloud_and_mobile. During his free time, he likes to practice sports, especially doing a lot of climbing and snowboarding across France and Switzerland.
217756852.title: [Sponsored event] 3D on the Web. Modeling, VR, WebGL and three.js at Autodesk

222523608.description:
Seoul Digital Forum (SDF) and Seoul Tech Society present an opportunity to learn from fascinating experience and participate in an inspirational discussion with Francisco Vico, a professor of AI at University of Malaga, and Micha Benoliel, CEO and co-founder of Open Garden.

Agenda

The presentations by the speakers will be short and open-ended, and the topics are designed to open questions for the community to discuss. 


- 7:00pm, Gates Open

- 7:30pm, Session with Francisco Vico

If AI simply emerges, how will we anticipate its consequences?

We'll talk about the current D&Q approach to synthesizing intelligence, why we do it that way, and how we can get ready for it.

- 8:30pm, Session with Micha Benoliel

How do you think off-the-grid messaging is possible?

We will learn how ubiquitous mobile connectivity can reshape the way we connect and communicate - and how the future of connectivity will be powered by you, for you.

* we plan a post-meetup gathering in a relaxed environment, stay tuned

Bio

Francisco Vico

Francisco Vico is a full professor in Artificial Intelligence at University of Malaga. 

As a scientist, his main interest is the confluence of biology and computer science. As an engineer, his quest is to show computers their way to higher functions that will allow computers to express themselves, by talking with people, creating music, and perceiving the world just as humans do. 

Micha Benoliel

Micha Benoliel is the CEO and co-founder of Open Garden. 

Open Garden's purpose is to build a new decentralized mobile Internet. Open Garden is the developer of FireChat, the first off-the-grid messaging app, leveraging peer-to-peer mesh networking. Micha has been a pioneer in VoIP. At age 8, Micha taught himself how to code on a flight simulator in Basic on a Zenith PC that his father was using for accounting purposes. 

Seoul Digital Forum

SDF is one of the most ambitious and inspirational tech events which brings together fascinating global visionaries driving innovation in emerging areas.

SDF 2015 opens on May, 20-21 at Dongdaemun Design Plaza. On-site registration will be available except the morning sessions on the 20th.

Live blogger opportunity

SDF provides an opportunity to meet the speakers and actively participate in the event through live blogging (on their FB event page + Twitter).

Interested? Message them directly at their fb page https://www.facebook.com/SDF.kr (until May,18)

Details:

- a tech-savvy person who could be part of their team of live bloggers onsite (May 19 - 21)

- this is a volunteer position (lunches provided), and their live bloggers will have access to stage rehearsals & the press room / be able to conduct pre-interviews w/ 3 selected speakers / be given designated seats in the session hall.
222523608.title: [Collaboration w/ SDF] Meet global visionaries

225279453.description:
Bitcoin Center Korea

17 Sep join us with Petar Maymounkov, discussing past futures and present of the P2P systems. Petar, an engineer at Google, is one of the original authors of Kademlia algorithm that powers systems like BitTorrent, Etherium, eMule, etc.

Peer to peer systems (P2P) give ability to communicate, share information in a distributed manner among peers. These systems applied in various context such as file distribution systems, distributed computation platforms, botnets, etc. However there's still room for higher adoption. 

In this talk P.Maymounkov will talk about P2P systems, their adoption and possible hinder factors.

Speaker Bio:

Petar Maymounkov is most famous for his groundbreaking work on Kademlia: a distributed algorithm that enables billions of peers to store and discover information collaboratively. His educational background is as follows:

'12 - PhD, Computer Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

'03 - MSc, Compute Science, New York University

'01 - BA, Mathematics and Computer Science, Harvard University

Kademlia (with over 2000 citations) fuels many household software applications — LimeWire, BitTorrent, Overnet, EDonkey2000, eMule, Transmission, uTorrent, etc. 

In the security community, in 2011, Kaspersky Lab reports that one of the most evasive botnets, TDL4, is based on the Kad Network. And, in 2007, Symantec Security includes Kademlia in their taxonomy of cyber-security. 

P.Maymounkov's recent work includes GoCircuit.org: a system that simplifies the development of complex massively-scaled systems nearly to the level of their single-process counterparts which he developed while working as engineer at Tumblr.

Location

Bitcoin Center Korea is home to all things Bitcoin and more. Center provides educational classes, collaborative workshops, networking and other exciting events related to Bitcoin, FinTech or open source projects. In addition, Bitcoin Center Korea provides business development and incubation services.

http://bitcoincenterkorea.org/
https://www.facebook.com/bitcoincenterkorea
http://www.meetup.com/Bitcoin-Center-Korea/
225279453.title: What is preventing advancements in P2P software today

220919205.description:
What can be cooler and more futuristic than robots!? But this future is already coming and sooner than expected robots will be around us flying in skies,  serving at our houses or enhancing our bodies. 

Don't miss the chance to learn when the era of robots is coming and what technologies enable it.

Agenda

Prof. Lenskiy:

• What is ROS, how it is changing Robotics

• Flaws of CS education

• How we introduce robotics to improve CS education

Dr. Stonier:

• Where are we with Robotics?

• Who is doing what?

• ROS/OSRF and the international Robotics Community

• Why is it so challenging?

• Some Stories

        • Working on a Robotics Team

        • Working on a Robotics Product

• Do you have what it takes?

• Forging a new robotics business

Dr. Popov:

- What is exoskeleton and what are the possible applications?

- Why don’t we see them on streets yet?

- How to make a life-fissile robotic system?

- Exoskeleton start-up


Bio

Artem Lenskiy

Artem Lenskiy is a professor at Korea University of Technology and Education (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tk_3NsLDXhI univ promo video where he took part). He has broad range of interests including programming in different languages and data analysis applied in cryptocurrency and digital healthcare systems. One of his passion is research of robotics which he will share with SeoulTech.

Daniel Stonier

Daniel Stonier gets to work [play] with robots. All day. Every day. Something that most techie folk dream about or madly try to squeeze into their hobby time at the risk of raising the ire of their partners. He also gets to work with the international robotics community where you can find some of the most exciting and passionate young people on technologies that are quite literally walking out of movies into our lives. It’s not an easy career, and it is a long way from the farm he grew up on and the mathematics he studied and taught at university, but it’s never dull!

Dmitry Popov

Dmitry Popov is a researcher who has been working on bringing robotics into daily life by developing an exoskeleton for a daily assistance and rehabilitation. The ideas of building a robot that can enhance the abilities of a normal person will probably give you some excited feelings. Dmitry has been working with such robotics systems for the past 5 years, trying to make them actually feasible for a daily life.
It takes some patience and creativity to make a device that can be worn on your body, providing an extra power or speed, and will not disturb your natural motions or limit your casual activities. So far he has been successful in making several versions of upper limb soft exoskeleton. He has also big plans for commercialization.
220919205.title: Introduction to Robotics: technology, trends and live demos

222929110.description:
Legendary "Introduction to Robotics" in March was the biggest event at SeoulTech so far. Robotics 2.0 is coming with more topics, showcases and other opportunities.

And may be it will be time to create your own robots... 


Agenda


• 1.30pm, Gates Open


• 2pm, Dr Dmitriy Popov, Overview of state of the art robotic applications and wearable robotics

• 3pm, Prof Yongjae Kim, Introduction to interactive robotics, especially on the robot arms with safe and compliant mechanisms

• 4pm, Dr Taewook Kang, Building information modeling and robot-based architecture 

• 5pm, Prof Artem Lenskiy, What you need to know to make robots?

• 5:20pm, Dr Daniel Stonier, Robot demonstration.  

• 5:40pm, Summary, Q&A and discussions


Description

The robots are taking over, it is predicted that by 2025, 30% of the jobs will be performed by robots. The revolution is happening right now. In this event experts in robotics will share their opinions on the future of robotics as well as describe current achievements in robotics. We are planning to make this event interactive and demonstrate robotic systems.

Prof Yongjae Kim participated in Darpa robotics challenge 2015 (http://www.theroboticschallenge.org). This is a cutting edge of robotics that brings together experts form all around the world to compete between each other. Besides, Prof Kim worked for Samsung in a robotics division for over 10 years, he has got valuable experience about collaboration between the academia and the industry. Development of soft medical robots is one his specialities  among many projects he has been involved in. He is currently a Professor at Korea University of Technology and Education (Koreatech). 

Dr Daniel Stonier is a renowned expert in robotics, motion planning and simultaneous localization and mapping. Dr Stonier obtained his PhD in mathematics form Deakin University and has been  an innovation team co-leader at Yujin Robot since 2014.  Yujin Robot is a leader in designing and manufacturing of service robots.

Dr Dmitriy Popov just returned from  ICRA2015(http://icra2015.org), one of the best if not the best conferences in Robotics. Dr Popov will share his experience on the state of the art of robotic technologies presented at the conference with the emphasis on exoskeletons and rehabilitation robotics. He will also demonstrate his own wearable robotic glove. 

Dr Taewook Kang is a senior researcher at KICT(http://www.kict.re.kr/eng/)  and is interested in robotics applications to architecture (http://www.robotsinarchitecture.org/). Dr Kang besides being a  senior researcher at ICT lab at Korea institute of Civil Engineering and Building Engineering is a hobbyist. His hobby in robotics is now deeply merged with his job as a civil engineer. He will present his view on robotic applications in construction engineering and architecture.

Prof Artem Lenskiy and his students participated in a number of robotic projects including the autonomous military vehicle sponsored by agency for defense development and the autonomous vehicle competition organized by Hyundai Motors. Dr Lenskiy focuses on perceptional aspects of robots. Besides, Dr Lenskiy has been working on an educational mobile robot platform to improve computer science education.

244890850.description:
• Machine learning has gathered a lot of attention from the media and tech society as means to automate human thinking. Mainly, many online businesses have started realizing its value of providing better customer experience with less human intervention thanks to its ability to make real-time decisions from the vast amount of data.

• This talk will explain and demonstrate steps for an online business to benefit from its data science and machine learning initiative in a detailed and yet concise manner. It will first demonstrate building a recommendation engine from an e-commerce data set. Then, it will emphasize that building a machine learning model is only a beginning and that without appropriate deploying and maintaining of models, the online business might not see the fruits of its machine learning projects. It will move onto showing ways to productionize machine learning models using container and cloud technologies such as Docker and AWS. In the end, it will also share concrete tips related to building, deploying and managing machine learning models. The talk will be a little bit technical but it'd be useful for less-technical audience too to get to know some of potential obstacles in machine learning projects so that they can get to manage their projects easier in their organizations.

• The speaker: Ken Park, CEO of Knowru

The talk will be presented by Ken Park, CEO of Knowru. Through his career, he has witnessed and participated in multiple cases where successful analytics and machine learning initiatives transformed startup companies to become multi-million dollar companies, some of which successfully went to IPO. Currently, he and his company provide consulting services and software tools for data scientists and developers to successfully collaborate during their machine learning projects. He is a Chartered Financial Analyst and holds a master's degree in computer science from the University of Chicago.

Do not miss the chance to make new friends and free pizza. Knowu will provide the pizzas for STS community. 

Thank you. See you then.
244890850.title: Analyze, Train, Deploy - The Cycle of Machine Learning Project Explained!

169900682.description:
Our speaker this time is Dr. Ogan Gurel (LinkedIn profile), a prominent researcher and professional in the area of mHealth and digital medicine. He will introduce us to the world of emerging eHealth technologies.

If you want to team-up with smart and creative people of Seoul Tech Society, stay for the second part of the event! There will be a brainstorming session where we can put newly acquired knowledge to work and come up with an idea of an eHealth application together.

Agenda


4pm–5pm: eHealth trends by Dr. Ogan Gurel

5pm–6pm: brainstorming and teamup for an eHealth application


About Dr. Gurel


Dr. Gurel is a Director in the MOT Research Center / CTO Office at the Samsung Advanced Institute of Technology (SAIT).  He also holds an academic appointment as a Visiting Professor at the Samsung Advanced Institute for Health Sciences and Technology (SAIHST) of SungKyunKwan University.  Previously he was VP & Medical Director at Sg2 and an Associate at Booz, Allen & Hamilton where he consulted for both large and small clients spanning the healthcare services, health insurance, biopharma and medical device sectors.  

His expertise covers the healthcare industry widely, including the clinical, business, executive management, marketing and R&D, with direct experience along several verticals: medical devices, mobile health, healthcare IT, medical imaging, and pharmaceuticals. His scientific research focuses on structural biology, specifically protein electrodynamics and terahertz medicine.


His computer science interests included work on microprocessor software development systems, followed by robot programming systems work.

Venue

238318902.description:
We've all heard it: Asia is the future of technology. Over the past few decades, the Asian region has exploded in technological growth from cell phone hardware to call centers to software shops. 

But where does UX fit into the conversation? Why do Asian websites look so different than any other sites in the world? Why has adoption of UX methodologies been so slow in Asia?


In this presentation, Ben Kim from Apical Design will share his thoughts on the State of UX in Asia. He will draw from his experiences hosting several lectures in the region and multiple first-hand interviews with Asian designers. He'll also talk about how to bring a UX culture within your organizations. 

By the end, attendees will have a better understanding of how UX has progressed in the region and the tremendous possibilities moving forward.
238318902.title: The State of UX in Asia and How to Build a UX Culture in Your Organization

223269564.description:
This event will look at Public Key Infrastructure. We will show you how to generate your own keys, and how to electronically sign software and documents to improve customer trust.

Become a part of the web of trust: secure use of the Internet.


Have a key - come to share with others. Don’t have - we will help to create new one.

When everyone gets their own key, we will have a Key-signing PaRtY to exchange keys and start communicating securely.

Security can be fun, the Key-signing PaRtY will include light snack and drinks @ the outside terrace of D.CAMP.

Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) improves the security and trust in messages, documents, software and other data published from you or your company.


The event will include a brief introduction to PKI as well as a hands-on part and a key-signing party, don't miss fun.

Agenda:

* features the Key-signing PaRtY.
Key signing parties are a way to strengthen the web of trust. In public-key cryptography, the key signing party is an event at which people present their public keys to others in person.

• 6:45pm, Gates Open

• 7:00pm, PKI introduction

• 7:30pm, Hands-on: generate and use GPG (Windows, OSX, Linux) – Bring your laptops to follow along


• 8:30pm, Practical examples (Web-of-Trust, Paranoid.email) 

• 9:00pm, Key-signing PaRtY


Speakers:

Dr. Joshua I. James, Prof. Artem Lenskiy, Senior Security Analyst Max Goncharov.

7th International Conference on Digital Forensics and Cyber Crime (ICDF2C) with Seoul Tech Society announces a call for essays. Participate to share your thoughts about cyber crime and emerging cyber threats.

231263992.description:
A talk about the light and dark side of UX in the travel industry and how companies encourage us to day-dream about holidays whilst tricking us into purchasing things we don’t need.


About the talk

It’s been just over a 100 years since the first commercial passenger flight and what a century it’s been! In this talk we’ll discover the ways in which technology defines the way we plan our local and international adventures and how companies invest in UX that enables (and annoys) us in the process.

• Have you ever been frustrated in the middle of booking a flight when you suddenly realise the price has doubled and you're paying for travel insurance you didn’t ask for and a seat you didn’t choose?

• Have you ever wondered why airlines make such an effort to sell you rental cars and hotels?

• Do you want to see some split testing results that reveal some interesting user behaviour?


At the end of the talk we’ll open up a discussion to talk about recent trips we’ve had and how technology enabled us (or annoyed us).

About the speaker
Marton Bodonyi is a software engineer working in Melbourne, Australia at Rome2rio (http://www.rome2rio.com), a multi-modal travel search company that caters for over 8 million visitors per month and growing! He has over 6 years experience working in London and Melbourne on digital products and has recently started UsableTravel, a blog that discusses UX in the context of the travel industry.
231263992.title: UX & Travel with Marton Bodonyi (Rome2rio) from Melbourne Australia

Specifically, the meetup will cover the following topics:

1. Why FinTech?

2. Why Machine Learning for FinTech?

3. How FinTech does Machine Learning?

4. What challenges FinTech faced in using machine learning

5. How FinTech companies are solving the challenges

Pizzas and drinks will be provided.
239820341.title: How US and China FinTech companies do machine learning

Talk by Felipe Hoffa, Developer Advocate @Google

Revolutionary thinkers can create enormous wealth and massive life improvements - but only if they can gather the right data and technology sources to make their ideas possible. 

In this talk we are going to explore how we can accelerate this process with open data and technology. We'll feature some of the best tools created by Google, working together with enormous datasets openly available.

Felipe Hoffa moved from Chile to San Francisco to join Google as a Software Engineer. Since 2013 he's been a Developer Advocate on big data - to inspire developers around the world to leverage the Google Cloud Platform tools to analyze and understand their data in ways they could never before. You can find him in several YouTube videos, blog posts, and conferences around the world. 


@felipehoffa

228521897.description:
Seoul Tech Society is crazy about Papers We Love movement! 

This is an experimental meetup for everyone who is interested in Computer Science and User Experience Research and would like to study the most influential academic papers in the field together. 

This will be an introduction meeting, why don't we go easy and review well-known paper in the field: 

Designing for usability: key principles and what designers think. Gould, J. D. and Lewis, C. (1985)

Go to any UX conference and you'll hear the same points as those raised in this pioneering paper: early and continual focus on users; empirical measurement, iterative design. View Paper[pdf]


[Description by Measuringu]


Paper will be presented by organizers [Victoria Bondarchuk], would be great if participants read paper in advance and prepare questions for the discussion. 


If you have any suggestion or want to help organizing this meetup, please contact us! 

About Papers We Love: 

http://paperswelove.org/,  http://www.meetup.com/papers-we-love/

What was the last paper within the realm of computing you read and loved? What did it inspire you to build or tinker with? Come share the ideas in an awesome academic/research paper with fellow engineers, programmers, and paper-readers. Lead a session and show off code that you wrote that implements these ideas or just give us the lowdown about the paper (because of HARD MATH!). Otherwise, just come, listen, and discuss.

We're curating a repository for papers and places-to-find papers. You can contribute by adding PR's for papers, code, and/or links to other repositories.

We're posting videos of all our presentations, from all our chapters.  

If you need to reach out to us or have ideas for papers, just ask us via our twitter account.

Papers We Love has a Code of Conduct. Please contact one of the Meetup's organizers if anyone is not following it. Be good to each other and to the PWL community!

HOST

HIVE ARENA

A CURATED COMMUNITY

of creative and innovative individuals.

http://en.hivearena.com/

About John Frankel

John Frankel has been an early-stage venture investor since 1999. Mr. Frankel was one of the earliest investors in Quigo Technologies, which was purchased by AOL in December 2007, and in Cornerstone OnDemand (CSOD on NASDAQ) which had a successful IPO in March 2011. He has also served and/or now serves on the boards of 500px, Apparel Media Group, Alerts.com, Centzy, ClearPath Immigration, Gobbler, Infochimps, Klout, Phone.com, Quigo Technologies, The Goldman Sachs Trust Company, and Voxy. He is also a Mentor with the Entrepreneurs Roundtable Accelerator program.

In particular, he established Goldman’s Cayman offshore administration business, their London global custody business, and reengineered their global prime brokerage business. In capital markets, he worked closely with some of the world’s leading hedge funds, and developed a keen understanding of portfolio risk/return management. He started his business career with Arthur Anderson & Co. in the audit and insolvency divisions.

Mr. Frankel earned a Master of Arts from New College, Oxford where he studied Mathematics, Philosophy and Logic, and is a Fellow Chartered Accountant of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales.

165322992.description:
If you've ever visited Hacker News, you've almost certainly seen the "Show HN" or "Ask HN" posts. Well, it's time to get off the Internet and tell us about it face to face. We'll provide you with our honest feedback, you provide us with a great hack, or idea.

We'll give you 5 minutes to show off your tool, hack, library (did you just write a library to access the Meetup API in Go!?), whatever. We're language and software/hardware agnostic, so it's all fair game.

List of speakers:


• How to fail a Samsung App Challenge 

  Reflects the experience of a team hacking of Galaxy Note to create a productivity app based on convergence of S-Pen, Chord and 2nd-screen SDKs. 

seoultechsociety.org/post/[masked]/seoul-tech-rises-to-samsung-challenge

 

• BigData: Audit Log Manager prototype

   Taming big data through distributed processing and interactive visualization using hadoop and d3.js

• Zeppelin: open source data analysis environment


   Lee Moon Soo, CTO of NFLabs will tell us how he spent this autumn: designing and implementing of the large scale data analysis environment github.com/NFLabs/zeppelin

• Starting up a company:  developing and running a mobile app service "Mango Plate"

Danny Ryu, founder of www.mangoplate.com

• Library design: from idea to construction

Gorka Blas, architect will guide us through an award winning project of building a library. 

• Jamming at the Global Game Jam and international collaboration in Korea.  

Joe Spradley will share his experience of hosting the Game Jam.

 

Your project doesn't have to be a software project. We're using a very broad definition of hacking. Anything customized or personalized counts. Please don't feel shy.

After you present, it's an open forum. The audience will ask questions and provide feedback. We want to enable as much participation as possible at these meetups, so you'd better be able to take criticism and dish it out (all within reason of course).

159085522.description:
Introductory Session

This is the introductory session to a series of RaspberryPi workshops in collaboration with FabLab Seoul and innovation engineer Todd Holoubek.

On this event Todd will explain the basic concepts of what is an operating system, what is assembly code and other important basics. If you are interested in learning about RaspberryPi, you are welcome to visit this lecture for free. 

Bonus: you will get the chance to visit a real Fabrication Laboratory—a truly unique environment, and learn about technologies and benefits provided there.

Those who want to get their hands on RaspberryPi and make something real are welcome to participate in the subsequent series of workshops over the next four weeks.

http://t0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSU_qvh3dhFJmhnWkTo3uWGASJJ03OTVY23IOa9jUGeJRv9XLuCpA

RaspberryPi Workshop

This series of workshops is focused around the idea that we should not just make “things”, but that we should be innovating, experimenting, creating tools and systems that take us one step closer in understanding how our world works. By understanding how our world works, we are empowered to reshape our world!!

The outcome of these workshops will be an RFID logging and access system. Through designing and building this system, this series of workshops will teach:

• The basics of the Raspberry Pi platform

• Programming with the Python language

• Basic MySql database structure and commands

• Serial communication

• RFID technology

• Basic Electricity (with soldering)

The series of workshops is ₩40,000 which will be put towards food and beverages for each workshop! At the end of the workshops, each participant has the option to purchase their Raspberry Pi.!

About Todd Holoubek

Todd Holoubek, is raised on a small farm in Ixonia, Wisconsin. His teens to early twenties, are spent operating a small sports wear company and performing in the theatre. His undergraduate education is dedicated to the theater arts. He produces alive ensemble performance each semester for three years. Post-graduation the ensemble moves to television as “The State on MTV”, and runs through the mid 90’s.Post television, Todd attends graduate school at the Interactive Telecommunications Program, NYU. Graduating in 2001, he receives a residency at ITP. Over twenty years,in Manhattan, Todd grows into an artist and innovator of rich experiences. As a result,participants of his installations encounter media and technology through light sculptures, intriguing puzzles, and mischievous interactive works examining the bridge between humans, their technology, their media, and their cultures. In 2012, he moves to Korea.

http://www.toddholoubek.com

If you've ever visited Hacker News, you've almost certainly seen the “Show HN” or “Ask HN” posts. Well, it's time to get off the Internet and tell us about it face to face. We'll provide you with our honest feedback, you provide us with a great hack, or idea.


We'll give you 10 minutes to show off your tool, hack, library, an art project.  Great feedback from highly engaged audience is guaranteed! 

List of speakers: 


1. Mathis Büchi

“How we grew our site to 1.5 million users a month”

We increased our user base for our web application from a few dozen monthly visitors to 1.5 million within a year. 

2. Manuel Stofer

“Experiences scaling a web app”

Architectures we tried and problems we encountered while our web app grew from 1 to 30 servers.

3. FraSen Inc.: Tien Thinh Nguyen & Jackson Ra

“Hack Sleep”

Hardware engineer Tien Thinh Nguyen and product strategist Jackson Ra will talk about the wearable computing market and how optimizing the quality of your sleep can help you truly seize the day.

4. Jongwook Woo

“Big Data and Use Cases on Hadoop” 

5. Carsten Haitzler

“Long ago I thought my desktop was ugly. Writing a Window Manager can't be that hard... I decided to have a stab at is. This is its story”

Abstract:
When I was a student, I was introduced to UNIX and its display system - "The X Window System". Also knows as X11 or X. What made this usable was a "Window Manager". It gave you titlebars, the ability to move windows, resize them, virtual desktops, focus management etc. etc. ... At the time I had tried various Window Managers, and not being happy with Any of them I decided to teach myself C as a language, learn X11 and the raw libraries it was based on, and build myself a Window Manager. Now about 19 years later and over 1 million lines of C code still standing (not to mention all the code written, thrown away and replaced), a career now centered around it, It wasn't so hard, but I had no idea what I was getting into. This is my "best hack ever".


6. Hassan Abid, Sujin Lee

“How to build an effective online community in Korea; Challenges and Experiences”

232099500.description:
Where and how did AI come to light? What and where is AI ? What are its promises for the years to come ?


This talk will be a brief introduction to the subject, giving a few elements of answer to these questions.

SPEAKERS 

Mélissa Djuimo is a consultant and knowledge engineer working in Paris, France at Yseop, a software editor specialized in NLG (natural language generation). With a background in electrical engineering, AI called her around 2 years ago, since then she’s been interested in the challenge!

Mina Lee is an engineer at NFLabs, Machine Learning practitioner and PMC of Apache Zeppelin. She received BS in Business Administration and Statistics from Yonsei University. She is passionate about accelerating the adoption of Apache Zeppelin in data scientists world.

Romeo Patrick Ira, a software engineer and Artificial intelligence specialist. He is going to talk about his transition from backend software engineer to an AI startup founder, learning curve and "A hacker's approach to career planning in AI".


AGENDA

20:00 Chronicles of AI

Let’s make a time perspective of AI from its birth to nowadays for starters, and then take a look at what it is now and what it covers

20:20 Many faces of AI: real examples showcase

A slight review of sample day-to-day uses and implementations of AI by day-to-day makers. From the old robust expert systems, to the new promising machine learning tools.

20:45 Towards transcendence ?

Where does AI go from now on? This is a meta view of AI, its current challenges as well as its possible futures that experts in the field are predicting.

2014년 4월 4일, 플래툰 쿤스트할레는 미디어 아티스트 Lucia 이지선과 스페인 건축가 Gorka Blas 의 기획에 의해 미디어 아트, 건축, 디자인 등 다양한 분야의 15명의 젋은 창작자들의 협업으로 이루어진 결과물들로 채워질 예정입니다.


WHEN: FRIDAY, APRIL 4 @ 7PM
  About Art Director Team
Lucia 이지선 is a media artist working between New York and Seoul, graduate of Master’s program in Interactive Telecommunication at NYU. She has exhibited in The 13th Seoul International New Media Festival and 3LD Art and Technology Center(New York). She has taught at the Queens Museum of Art, Stevens Institute of Technology and Hostos Community College of New York. 

미디어 아티스트. 뉴욕대 Interactive Telecommunication Program 석사과정 이후 제 13회 서울 국제 뉴미디어 축제, 3LD Art & Technology Center 등 뉴욕과 서울에서 전시 및 Queens Museum of Art, Stevens Institute of Technology and Hostos Community College of New York 에서 강사로 활동
smellsdreamy.com / facebook.com/luciajeesunlee


Gorka Blas is an architect, born in Spain. He has worked for several architectural practices in Madrid and London, including Zaha Hadid Architects and Crab Architects among others. In 2012, he won UIA International Architecture competition for Daegu Gosan library in Korea and in 2013 he was awarded a special mention in the European 12 competition. He has taught and given lectures both in Italy and Korea. His project for the Daegu Gosan library is currently in 
construction.

238436759.description:
Audience: intermediate or advanced developers and cyber security professionals.

Presenter: A young but battle-tested hacker.

Content:

This presentation will show you how any communication can be hacked. Femtocell devices serve LTE for three big telecommunication companies in South Korea (and not only) but can be exposed.

The presentation shows real demos of the process of exposure, the way to approach femtocell devices on the test service and the way to get the firmware. How to analyze and find vulnerabilities will be explained. We will look also at SMS and call voice packets sent and received by the exposed femtocells.

Agenda:

7:30 - Gates open

7:45 - Hacking femtocell, by Real Hacker

8:30 - Q&A

What is this Meetup about? / 이 교육은 도대체 무엇인가요?

3D design, printing, and post-processing as usual. We will show you how to design your own simple mechanical device. No previous design experience is necessary! Then, we will show you how to prepare your file for 3D printing. Then you will learn how to 3D print your model. Easy right?

이 교육을 설명해드리자면 3D디자인, 3D프린팅, 및 후처리를 가르쳐 드립니다. 3D 모델링 경험이 없어도 상관 없습니다! 나만의 심플 디바이스 직접~! 만들기 위한 3D 모델링하는 방법을 가르쳐 드리고, 3D 프린터 작동원리와 사용방법, 슬라이싱 프로그램 모두 배우게 되며, 마지막으로 여러분이 설계한 3D 모델을 출력 방법을 배우게 됩니다. 참 쉽죠? :)

(This is a Seoul clone of the original NYC Hack and Tell Meetup event!)

If you've ever visited Hacker News, you've almost certainly seen the "Show HN" or "Ask HN" posts. Well, it's time to get off the Internet and tell us about it face to face. We'll provide you with our honest feedback, you provide us with a great hack, or idea.

We'll give you 5 minutes to show off your tool, hack, library (did you just write a library to access the Meetup API in Go!?), whatever. We're language and software/hardware agnostic, so it's all fair game.

Your project doesn't have to be a software project. We're using a very broad definition of hacking. Anything customized or personalized counts. Please don't feel shy.

After you present, it's an open forum. The audience will ask questions and provide feedback. We want to enable as much participation as possible at these meetups, so you'd better be able to take criticism and dish it out (all within reason of course).

245276201.description:
Want to monetize your data while conforming to privacy and security? Are you an AI startup that is starving for data? Are you looking for the next big thing in blockchain and cryptocurrencies?

We bring you Ocean Protocol ( https://oceanprotocol.com/ ), where data is the most valuable asset.

Ocean Protocol, supported by BigchainDB (https://www.bigchaindb.com/) from Berlin and DEX (https://www.dex.sg/) from Singapore, is a decentralised data exchange protocol that allows people share and monetise data while guaranteeing control, auditability, transparency, and compliance to everyone involved. It also offers developability through open access for developers to create new and innovative services. It aims to nurture a data ecosystem and community where more data can be made available for data analytics and AI. The protocol is powered by an added native token, OCN, which serves as the means of exchange within the network.

19:30 – 20:00: Networking Reception

20:00 – 20:45: Presentation by Bruce Pon and Chirdeep Chhabra

20:45 – 21:00: Q&A from audience

21:00 – 21:30: Networking Reception

Come down and meet Bruce Pon (https://www.linkedin.com/in/ponbruce/) and Chirdeep Chhabra (https://www.linkedin.com/in/chirdeep/) on Thursday, 30 November. They will take you through Ocean Protocol and its vision to revolutionise how businesses share and apply data, and unlock data for artificial intelligence.

You don’t want to miss out if you are a data provider, data consumer, miner, developer, or specialist in data, blockchain, Artificial Intelligence, or cryptocurrencies. Watch for more info:

https://youtu.be/FEeicvNSyk4


SPEAKERS

BRUCE PON | FOUNDER

Bruce Pon is the CEO and co-founder of BigchainDB, a decentralized blockchain database. Prior to BigchainDB, Bruce co-founded Avantalion International Consulting, a consulting firm specialized in building banks and industry startups in Europe and Asia for companies such as Mercedes-Benz, Volkswagen, Mitsubishi. Bruce is a board member, advisor and investor in six startups. He has an Advanced Executive Certificate from MIT Sloan and a B.Sc in Engineering from the University of Saskatchewan.

CHIRDEEP CHHABRA | FOUNDER

Chirdeep Singh Chhabra is the founder of Ocean Protocol, a decentralised data exchange protocol to unlock data for AI. Chirdeep is also the CEO of DEX, a data marketplace enabling trusted data exchange. Prior to Ocean Protocol and DEX, Chirdeep was the head of Data Programmes at the Digital Catapult in London. A serial entrepreneur and investor, Chirdeep has a masters in distributed systems from EPFL Switzerland and is a Chevening Fellow, CSEL entrepreneurship graduate, from London Business school in UK.

You can also visit the Ocean Protocol Medium https://blog.oceanprotocol.com/ to learn more.

Be part of our Meetup Group https://www.meetup.com/Ocean-Protocol/ to engage in discussions and put forward your ideas and feedback to the community. We value your contributions, so join in the conversations today!
245276201.title: Ocean Protocol: A Decentralised Data Exchange Protocol by BigchainDB and DEX

221206161.description:
If you follow the media, you might be under impression that Seoul is the new Silicon Valley and startup ecosystem is blossoming here. In reality, however, the majority of people are stuck in large enterprises, and don’t even know where to begin when it comes to setting up a company.

That is why we invited Hongseok Choe from Seoul Global Center to cover the basics of setting up a company in Seoul with specialties such as: obtaining the visa,  getting funding and entering the market.

To put the local startup ecosystem into a perspective, we invited speakers from Singapore Management University to cover the entrepreneurial opportunities in Singapore, a country famous for its mature startup ecosystem.

On Thursday, April 30 let’s find out together whether Singapore or Seoul these days have more opportunities for starting your own technology company.


Agenda:

Hongseok Choe — Seoul Global Center

“How to start a business in Seoul as a foreigner”

Hongseok is the go to man when it comes to setting up a company in Seoul as a foreigner. He knows ins and outs of the process of starting a company, from obtaining the visa to getting funding and entering the market.

Junghee Kee — SMBA

“The Korean policy for establishing a technology start-up ecosystem and the programs that support foreigners”

Junghee works for SMBA as a main person in charge of global startup program. As an official, she is also engaged in various governmental startup programs. She is one of the most knowledgeable people in Korean startup ecosystem.


Zu Cheng and Tat Loong — Singapore Management University

“Technopreneurship in Singapore”

Zu Cheng and Tat Loong will give an introduction to Singaporean startup scene. They would be looking at the history, the factors, the current climate of entrepreneurship (specifically in technology) and the future for budding entrepreneurs in Singapore.

187283782.description:
What is LaunchLab?


As part of the Launch - Hack - Tell cycle of innovation, SeoulTech is proud to announce the Launch Lab series of meetups.  This is a new type of event where researchers, entrepreneurs and innovators discuss and propose (any) project, and solicit ideas and help from other SeoulTech members.

Why?


Launch Lab helps members take one giant leap beyond networking. These events allow members  to get involved with the creation of new ideas or startups, while forging friendships and business partnerships to last a lifetime. 

How? 

The event features a group of speakers that give a 10 to 15 minute presentation of their idea. The audience then discusses the idea. Audience members can also choose to join or further contribute to the project.

Open discussion sessions will also be available, so if anyone gets inspired they can share and discuss their ideas with the group.

When?

June 28th, 2014

14:00 - 18:00: Presentations + Discussion + Coffee/Beer/Snacks

18:00 - 20:00: Dinner (possible group discount depending on number)

If you are a researcher, startup founder, entrepreneur, idea generator, or dreamer, sign up to be a speaker!

If you want to play in the Open Mic night, please let us know. Guitar will be provided.

Please email: Joshua [at] cybercrimetech.com

Note: This event is currently hosted outside of Seoul (Jukjeon - accessible by bus or Seoul Metro, 40 mins from Gangnam) - think as a half day picnic-style relaxing event.

144302832.description:
Do you spend more and more time with your digital devices? So do criminals who are finding new ways to take advantage of these hyper-connected technologies.

Our honored guests Dr. Joshua James and Security Consultant Michał Rzepka will guide you through the cyber world of white and black forces.

Featured

Bring your Windows laptop to practice being a cyber-sleuth with a practical lab on computer memory acquisition and analysis.

Agenda

Web vulnerabilities - what developers do for you to stay insecure

Talk about simple, old, known, yet still very popular weaknesses in web apps that affect users - basically everyone, since we all use web.

Cybercrime and digital forensics - what cyber cops do

This talk will give an overview of what cybercrime is, what cybercops do, and how digital forensic investigations are conducted.

Memory acquisition and analysis - hands on

During this practical you will learn to take a copy of Random Access Memory and extract evidence of user activity, such as pictures, web addresses and passwords.

Speakers

Dr. Joshua James is a researcher with the Digital Forensics Investigation Laboratory as well as a lecturer and researcher with University College Dublin, Korea University, Korea National Police University and Soon Chun Hyang University. Coming from a background in network security and administration, his focus is now on the formalization and automation of digital forensic investigation methods, and the application of these methods in low cost, open source solutions for digital investigators.

Michał Rzepka was previously working as a Security Engineer in national computing center and taking part in several national and European projects, Michał is currently working as a Security Consultant for the leading IT Security company in Northern Europe. His areas of experience include penetration testing, web application security assessing, as well as PCI DSS compliance.
144302832.title: Stay safe in the cyberspace

227105297.description:
Greetings fellow makers, tinkerers, designers, and inventors! We at Ateam Ventures and Fab Lab Seoul are excited to be hosting this event series with Seoul Tech Society.

안녕하세요 메이커, 디자이너 여러분. 저희 에이팀 벤처스, 팹랩 서울 팀원들은 Seoul Tech Society와  같이 이번 이벤트를 개최하게 되어 매우 흥분됩니다! :)

Why are we doing this? (우리는 왜 이것을 하고 있냐구요?)

This coming weekend, we want to provide you with a two-part community workshop.

The first part of the workshop (10:30 AM - 12:00 Noon) will be for beginners to 3D printing in which we will teach you how to model your own keychain. You will need to bring your own (1) laptop/computer, (2) mouse with left/right click and scroll wheel and (3) download Autodesk 123D Design before we begin (http://www.123dapp.com/design). You will also need to bring 5,000 KRW for material costs (to be collected at the beginning of the workshop). As a special discount, if you post a picture on facebook of your 3D print or our 3D printer and tag us in the picture (@ATEAM Ventures), you will get 4,000 KRW back! Please make sure you complete steps (1), (2), and (3) all before you come to Fab Lab on Saturday!

The second part of the workshop (1:00 PM to 2:30 PM) will be for people who already have a little bit of 3D printing experience already, or have completed the first part of the workshop. We will have materials for polishing both PLA and ABS printed objects, and a rotary tool and spare filament for friction welding. This second part of the workshop is totally free. We only ask that you bring your printed ABS and PLA objects, your friends, and of course yourself!

What do we hope to accomplish? (우리는 무엇을 달성 희망 합니까?)

By the end of the first part of the workshop, you will feel comfortable enough with the 3D modeling process to make your own keychains, and the 3D printing process to start exploring on your own.

What exactly will we be doing this coming meetup (November 21st)? (이번 모임에서 정확히 무엇을 하는건가요?(11/21))

In the first part of the workshop (10:30 AM - 12:00 Noon), we will guide you through the process of 3D modeling and printing your own keychain. We will show you how to sketch out a design in 2D, extrude that 2D sketch to make it 3D, convert your model into g-code using Cura, and then how to start a print on a 3D printer.

For the 3D printing veterans, during the second part of the workshop (1:00 - 2:30 PM) our acetone vapour chamber and tetrahydrofuran, and Dremel for friction welding will be available for you to use. We will answer your questions or help you set something up however we can.

What you need to bring if you are coming to the first part of the workshop (10:30 AM - 12:00 Noon)

1) Yourself and any and all interested friends

2) Your laptop/computer with Autodesk 123D Design downloaded (http://www.123dapp.com/design)

3) A mouse with left/right click and scroll wheel

4) 5,000 KRW cash to cover material costs (plastic for the 3D printers) [All "profits" are donated to Fab Lab Seoul!]

What you need to bring if you are coming to the second part of the workshop (1:00 PM - 2:30 PM)

1) Yourself and any and all interested friends

2) Your plastic models (PLA and ABS) if you would like to do some polishing or friction welding outside of the organised workshop (totally free free free!)

How, where, and when are these events happening? (언제, 어디서, 어떻게 이벤트가 진행되는건가요?)

We plan on holding these "workshops" every other Saturday from 10:30 AM to 12:00 AM (Part 1) and 1:00 PM to 2:30 PM, the closest workshop being this December 5th [masked]) at Fab Lab Seoul. Eduardo Charmorro (Fab Lab Seoul) and Joseph Choi (Ateam Ventures) will be there at the very least to provide guidance as needed. We will be charging a minor fee to cover material costs (plastic for the 3D printers). As always, please consider donating to Fab Lab Seoul so we can keep on upgrading the tools and supplies we can provide both you and all your fellow makers!

Suggest Resources

If you want to print a 3D model before coming but don't have printer, consider using Shapengine (http://www.shapengine.com/) website, they can print it for you before the event

Happy making!

Feel free to contact Joseph Choi [masked] if you have any questions or suggestions. Hope to see you soon!

Linux 101 - Introduction to Linux by Raphael Chambers, the inspiring member of the Seoul Tech Society.


Linux is a free and open source operating system which is gaining momentum and is a great alternative to other more well marketed OS's.

227689577.description:
Who are we? / 우리가 누구일까요?

We are Ateam Ventures, a 3D printing startup. We want to spread the word that starting your 3D printing journey is easy, and help you get started with some simple workshops. Thank you to Fab Lab Seoul for supplying us with the resources and space, and Seoul Tech Society for helping us reach you, our wonderful community!

우리는 Ateam Ventures 이라는 3D 프린팅 벤처기업 입니다. 저희 간단한 워크샵을 통해 3D 프린팅이 쉽다는 것을 보여드리고 싶습니다. 교육에 필요한 공간과 시간을 제공해준 팹랩 서울에게 감사드리며, 이러한 교육 의 기회를 연결 해주신 Seoul Tech Society에게 도 감사드립니다!

What is this Meetup about? / 이 교육은 도대체 무엇인가요?

3D design, printing, and post-processing as usual. We will show you how to design your own bottle opener. No previous design experience is necessary! Then, we will show you how to prepare your file for 3D printing. Then you will 3D print your model. Finally, you will learn how to polish your model to make it look even better. Easy right?

이 교육을 설명해드리자면 3D디자인, 3D프린팅, 및 후처리를 가르쳐 드립니다. 3D 모델링 경험이 없어도 상관 없습니다! 나만의  필통을 직접~! 만들기 위한 3D 모델링하는 방법을 가르쳐 드리고, 3D 프린터 작동원리와 사용방법, 슬라이싱 프로그램 모두 배우게 되며, 마지막으로 여러분이 설계한 3D 모델을 출력을 한 뒤 후가공 방법까지 배우게 됩니다. 참 쉽죠? :)

What do you need to bring to the Meetup? / 수업에 뭘 준비해가야 하나요?

• Your laptop / 노트북

• A mouse with a scroll wheel / 스크롤 휠이 있는 마우스

**************************************************************

• You need to download OpenSCAD, a free 3D modeling software (http://www.openscad.org/downloads.html) / OpenSCAD이라는 무료 3D 모델링 소프트웨어를 다운로드해야 합니다 (http://www.openscad.org/downloads.html)

**************************************************************

• 5,000 KRW (cash please) to cover material costs / 재료 값에 충당되는 오천원의 비용

When is the Meetup happening? / 행사는 언제죠?

• This meetup will take place on Saturday [masked]) from 10:30 AM to 12:00 Noon. / 저희는 이 수업을 01월 16일부터 격주에 한번 씩, 토요일 10시반부터 12시까지 팹랩서울에서 진행합니다.

• Because desktop organizers take a long time to print, you will have to pick up your desktop organizer either at the following workshop [masked]) or schedule a time to come visit me at my office to pick it up. / 필통을 출력하는 시간이 오래 걸릴 수 있기 때문에, 수업시간에 출력하지 못했다면 다음 워크샵이 진행되는 1월 30일에 출력물을 가져가야합니다. 또는 다음 워크샵 시간이 가능하지 않다면  별도의 시간을 예약 할 수 있습니다.

Where is the Meetup happening? / 교육은는 어디서 열리는가?

• The meetup will take place at Fab Lab Seoul. / 교육은 팹랩 서울에서 진행됩니다.

• 서울특별시 종로구 장사동 116-4 세운상가 550호

• Jangsadong 116-4, Sewoon Sang-ga #550 Jong-Ro_Gu, Seoul, Korea


• You can use Naver Maps to navigate to either (1) Jongno 3-Ga Station in the top left corner, (2) Euljiro 3-Ga Station in the bottom left corner, (3) Euljiro 4-Ga Station in the bottom right corner, and then get to Fab Lab Seoul by walking (it is on the 5th floor of the complex). 

Parking

• 출발 = Your Starting Point (The Parking Lot)

• 도착 = Your Destination (Fab Lab Seoul)

Did I forget anything?

Leave a question in the comments section below and I will get back to you as soon as I can! / 아래의 코멘트 섹션에서 질문을 해주시면 최대한 빠르게 대답해 드리겠습니다.

Additional resources

• Ateam Ventures Main Website: http://ateamventures.com/

• Creatable D2 (3D Printer) Main Website: http://creatablelabs.com/

• Shapengine (3D Printing Service) Main Website: http://shapengine.com/

• Fab Lab Seoul Main Website: http://fablab-seoul.org/

Connect with us! / 우리와 연결 하세요!

• Ateam Ventures: https://www.facebook.com/AteamVentures/?fref=ts

• Creatable Labs: https://www.facebook.com/creatablelabs/?fref=ts

• Shapengine: https://www.facebook.com/Shape-Engine-1472065846443586/?fref=ts

• Fab Lab Seoul: https://www.facebook.com/fablabseoul/?fref=ts

A Preview of What We Will Be Making!

•  It looks very simple I know, but I think this quick tutorial will go through many of the essential tools of OpenSCAD. The point is for you to learn enough to make your own really great stuff :)
